Levels.0: Voices not present or present less than once a week
Levels.1: Voices occur for at least once a week
Levels.2: Voices occur at least once a day
Levels.3: Voices occur at least once a hour
Levels.4: Voices occur continuously or almost continuously i.e. stop for only a few seconds or minutes

Levels.1: Voices last for a few seconds, fleeting voices
Levels.3: Voices last for at least one hour
Levels.4: Voices last for hours at a time

Levels.1: Voices sound like they are inside head only
Levels.2: Voices outside the head, but close to ears or head. Voices inside the head may also be present
Levels.3: Voices sound like they are inside or close to ears and outside head away from ears
Levels.4: Voices sound like they are from outside the head only

Levels.2: About same loudness as own voice

auditory5.Description: Auditory hallucinations: Beliefs re-origin of voices

Levels.1: Believes voices to be solely internally generated and related to self
Levels.2: Holds <50% conviction that voices originate from external causes
Levels.3: Holds >=50% conviction (but <100%) that voices originate from external causes
Levels.4: Believes voices are solely due to external causes (100% conviction)

auditory6.Description: Auditory hallucinations: Amount of negative content of voices

Levels.2: Minority of voice content is unpleasant or negative (<50%)
Levels.3: Majority of voice content is unpleasant or negative (>=50%)
Levels.4: All of voice content is unpleasant or negative

auditory7.Description: Auditory hallucinations: Degree of negative content

Levels.1: Some degree of negative content, but not personal comments relating to self or family e.g. swear words or comments not directed to self, e.g. 'the milkman's ugly'
Levels.2: Personal verbal abuse, comments on behaviour e.g. 'shouldn't do that or say that'
Levels.3: Personal verbal abuse relating to self-concept e.g. 'you're lazy, ugly, mad, perverted'
Levels.4: Personal threats to self e.g. threats to harm self or family, extreme instructions or commands to harm self or others

Levels.1: Voices occasionally distressing, majority not distressing (<10%)
Levels.3: Majority of voices distressing, minority not distressing (>=50%)

Levels.2: Voices are distressing to a moderate degree
Levels.3: Voices are very distressing, although subject could feel worse
Levels.4: Voices are extremely distressing, feel the worst he/she could possibly feel

auditory10.Description: Auditory hallucinations: Disruption to life caused by voices

Levels.0: No disruption to life, able to maintain social and family relationships (if present)
Levels.1: Voices causes minimal amount of disruption to life e.g. interferes with concentration although able to maintain daytime activity and social and family relationships and be able to maintain independent living without support
Levels.2: Voices cause moderate amount of disruption to life causing some disturbance to daytime activity and/or family or social activities. The patient is not in hospital although may live in supported accommodation or receive additional help with daily living skills
Levels.3: Voices cause severe disruption to life so that hospitalisation is usually necessary. The patient is able to maintain some daily activities, self-care and relationships while in hospital. The patient may also be in supported accommodation but experiencing severe disruption of life in terms of activities, daily living skills and/or relationships
Levels.4: Voices cause complete disruption of daily life requiring hospitalization. The patient is unable to maintain any daily activities and social relationships. Self-care is also severely disrupted.

Levels.0: Subject believes they can have control over the voices and can always bring on or dismiss them at will
Levels.1: Subject believes they can have some control over the voices on the majority of occasions
Levels.2: Subject believes they can have some control over their voices approximately half of the time
Levels.3: Subject believes they can have some control over their voices but only occasionally. The majority of the time the subject experiences voices which are uncontrollable
Levels.4: Subject has no control over when the voices occur and cannot dismiss or bring them on at all

voices_single_words.Description: Number of voices uttering single words or phrases without pronouns

auditory_duration.Description: Duration of auditory hallucinations in years

delusion1.Description: Delusions: Amount of preoccupation with delusions

Levels.0: No delusions, or delusions which the subject thinks about less than once a week
Levels.1: Subject thinks about beliefs at least once a week
Levels.2: Subject thinks about beliefs at least once a day
Levels.3: Subject thinks about beliefs at least once an hour
Levels.4: Subject thinks about delusions continuously or almost continuously

delusion2.Description: Delusions: Duration of preoccupation with delusions

Levels.1: Thoughts about beliefs last for a few seconds, fleeting thoughts
Levels.2: Thoughts about delusions last for several minutes
Levels.3: Thoughts about delusions last for at least 1 hour
Levels.4: Thoughts about delusions usually last for hours at a time

Levels.1: Very little conviction in reality of beliefs, <10%
Levels.2: Some doubts relating to conviction in beliefs, between 10–49%
Levels.3: Conviction in belief is very strong, between 50–99%

Levels.1: Beliefs cause distress on the minority of occasions
Levels.2: Beliefs cause distress on <50% of occasions
Levels.3: Beliefs cause distress on the majority of occasions when they occur between 50–99% of time
Levels.4: Beliefs always cause distress when they occur
Beliefs cause extreme distress, could not be worse

delusion6.Description: Delusions: Disruption to life caused by beliefs

Levels.0: No disruption to life, able to maintain independent living with no problems in daily living skills. Able to maintain social and family relationships (if present)
Levels.1: Beliefs cause minimal amount of disruption to life, e.g. interferes with concentration although able to maintain daytime activity and social and family relationships and be able to maintain independent living without support
Levels.2: Beliefs cause moderate amount of disruption to life causing some disturbance to daytime activity and/or family or social activities. The patient is not in hospital although may live in supported accommodation or receive additional help with daily living skills
Levels.3: Beliefs cause severe disruption to life so that hospitalisation is usually necessary. The patient is able to maintain some daily activities, self-care and relationships while in hospital. The patient may be also be in supported accommodation but experiencing severe disruption of life in terms of activities, daily living skills and/or relationships
Levels.4: Beliefs cause complete disruption of daily life requiring hospitalization. The patient is unable to maintain any daily activities and social relationships. Self-care is also severely disrupted
